field_edited_text.value:
Future Opportunities

The waterfront in Fells Point and Can-
ton offers the unique opportunity of devel-
oping a major new residential community
along an historic working waterfront. Vacant
warehouses and commercial buildings
stand ready for rehabilitation. Derelict piers
and crumbling shorelines could be rebuilt
for marinas, public promenades, and water-
front parks.

Among the most promising future
development sites on the western shoreline
of Fells Point are: .

*Brown’s Wharf: Located at Thames
Street, this parcel includes just over an
acre of vacant land on the waterfront
and the historic Brown’s Wharf, ware-
houses constructed in the early 19th
century.

*Terminal Corp. Warehouse: A large
brick warehouse on Thames Street with
waterfront on three sides. One of the
most prominent buildings along the
Fells Point waterfront. =

*Jackson Wharf: Just west of the Ter-
minal warehouse on Thames at Caro-
line, Jackson’s Wharf is also a large
brick warehouse with access to the
shoreline. There is also a small amount
of vacant land adjacent to the building
along the waterfront.

The above sites and a number of
properties inland are currently owned by a
developer.

The Canton waterfront was designated
an urban renewal area in 1984. There are
several opportunities along this shoreline to
provide facilities for both new residents
and visitors as well as Canton’s existing
citizens:

*]. S. Young Property: Located in Can-
ton on Boston Street this parcel and the
adjoining properties of the John Ren-
neberg Co. and Marine Repair Services
offer long-range redevelopment poten-
tial. Preliminary plans have been pre-
pared for the J. S. Young property
which includes a recreationally oriented
office/commercial complex and a full-
service marina. -



*Canton Waterfront Park: The City,
with assistance from the State’s Depart-
ment of Natural Resources is moving
to purchase approximately ten acres of
waterfront land at Boston Street
between Linwood and Clinton Streets.
The site will be developed for a large
waterfront park, a boat launch, and as
a permanent home for Baltimore’s
Marine Police and DPW’s Marine
Division.

*Vacant Land North of Boston Street:
Working with the Canton community,
the City has proposed redevelopment
of approximately 16 acres of vacant .
land. The proposal envisions an expan-
sion of the existing park immediately to
the east and development of the re-
maining 11 acres of land for town-
houses compatable with the Canton
community. This includes a nursing
home and approximately 160 units of
moderately priced housing.

*Linwood Associates Building: This
large warehouse at Boston and Lin-
wood offers redevelopment opportuni-
ties for a variety of uses. The ground
floor could provide much needed
parking and the building offer excel-
lent views of Ft. McHenry and the port.

Linwood Associates building, Canton waterfront, part of the once active cannery row along Boston St.
